awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The spreading of perceived exclusion
awd_abstract_narration:
Loneliness is a public health concern.  People who feel socially disconnected from others show reductions in psychological and physical well-being.  They behave in more antisocial or aggressive ways and they suffer declines in cognitive abilities and motivation.  Given the pain and harm of being socially disconnected, it is unfortunate that people often incorrectly perceive others as being the cause of social exclusion even when they are not.  This research seeks to identify the factors that make people vulnerable or resilient to false perceptions of exclusion.  It will examine people's responses to these social misunderstandings.  The long-term goal is to develop interventions that can help people identify when they may be falsely perceiving exclusion and how such misunderstandings can be addressed before they lead to harmful consequences.

This research focuses on a common, but ambiguous, social dynamic: one-person exclusion. This unfolds when one person (the excluder) includes another (the included) while excluding a third (the rejected).  Such dynamics are very common in everyday life. They may occur, for example, when one person (the excluder) invites another (the included) to an event while not inviting another person (the rejected).  Past work shows that although the included has not contributed to the exclusion, the rejected incorrectly perceives the included as having exclusive inclinations and likely to perpetuate exclusion in the future.  This phenomenon has been called the involuntary excluder effect.  This project examines one-person exclusion as it unfolds in naturalistic social settings over time.  Using a variety of research methods and measures (self-report, behavioral, cognitive, and neurophysiological), the experiments address questions such as: What gives rise to false perceptions of exclusion?  How do rejected persons behave toward those who are included by an excluder?  When might included individuals succumb to pressures of the social dynamic and become excluders themselves?  Ultimately, the research considers whether social misunderstandings are better corrected by training people to recognize when their perceptions might be faulty or by encouraging those caught in the middle of exclusionary dynamics (the included) to take proactive steps to signal that they are inclusive.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In 2023, the US Surgeon General Advisory called attention to the public health crisis of loneliness. The present work speaks to this warning by studying a misperception (the Involuntary Excluder Effect; IEE) that arises in one-person social exclusion situations.

A central aim of the project was to examine the extent to which this misperception occurs in real-life settings. Our studies find that even in in-person, face-to-face situations, where people have ample information to ascertain who are viable interaction partners, perceivers still show evidence of the IEE (i.e., those who are rejected by an excluder while someone else is included inaccurately perceive the included as likely to exclude them in the future). Moreover, this misperception also occurs in established relationships, such as when one's friend is invited to an event that one is not invited to. Being excluded when a friend is included undermines the rejected person's trust and confidence in the included friend's feelings and intentions.

An important goal of the project was to identify different routes to mitigate the negative consequences of one-person exclusion. Our studies find that the included's actions have the power to undo the IEE; by clearly signaling their inclusive stance towards the rejected, the included can disambiguate their intentions. Unfortunately, included persons are hesitant to intervene. They think that reassuring the rejected or mildly reprimanding the excluder would prove awkward and uncomfortable. But these forecasts are wrong. When the included were pushed to engage in these strategies, their actions not only undid the IEE, but their interactions proceeded more smoothly than they had anticipated.

A different set of studies systematically examined the effectiveness of social-presence interventions. Our studies find that such interventions do not undo the IEE, but do alleviate some of the emotional distress elicited by one-person exclusion. Simply having a short conversation with a friend or even an unknown peer can lessen the negative sting of one-person exclusion and restore feelings of belonging and personal control. Simply being in the presence of a friend conferred no appreciable affective benefits. These findings highlight the persistence of the IEE across different social contexts, and identify important ingredients of social presence interventions that alleviate the emotional distress elicited by one-person exclusion.

Critically, this project investigated one-person exclusion dynamics from the perspective of those who are caught in the middle (the included). In so doing, our studies identified an important theoretically significant boundary condition: the severity of the exclusion. When the excluder's behavior is clear-cut (e.g., do not invite a person to an event), and thus viewed as morally wrong, the included takes a stance of wanting to include the rejected. But when the excluder's behavior is more ambiguous (e.g., give more attention and show preference to one person), and thus viewed as morally permissible, then the included is presented with a moral conflict -- the competing motivations of wanting to be inclusive and wanting to reciprocate the interest of another. Importantly, third-party observers agree that preferential treatment is morally permissible, and thus worthy of being reciprocated, which highlights how subtle forms of exclusion may be condoned, but still have negative affective consequences for those who are rejected.

The project also broadly examined how people parse complex social situations that consist of rewarding cues (e.g., promise of affiliation) and threatening cues (e.g., potential or reality of exclusion and rejection), and the behaviors associated with these perceptions. Delineating the psychological processes by which people quickly assess rewards and threats is critical for understanding how they make sense of ambiguous social dynamics.

Results from the grant have been disseminated to the scientific community at conferences as well as articles (when accepted for publication after the end of the grant period). The grant has provided educational opportunities to undergraduate, graduate, and post-doctoral students from diverse backgrounds who have been instrumental in all aspects of the research process.

This grant led to the creation and production of a 3-minute educational video aimed at 9-18 year-olds, which will be disseminated via an engaged learning program to 4-12 graders, and via social media. The video educates children and adolescents who are particularly sensitive to social cues about human beings' need for social connection, potential for misperceptions in social dynamics, and ways to identify the misperception and prevent it.

Overall, this work has uncovered findings critical to combatting the epidemic of loneliness that marks today's society. People routinely encounter situations where another person is included when they are not, and such dynamics can lead to misperceptions of the included with dire consequences. But neither the misperception nor the negative affective consequences are inevitable. Increasing awareness of the phenomenon and ways to combat it can disrupt potential harms.
